text: Pours a black color with khaki head. Full of flavor. Bread aromas and malty

Pours a deep caramel brown with a thin tan head that left partial lace. Pleasant aroma of malt, caramel, mild toast, and a touch of prune. The flavor is similar with big malt leading the way, caramel, and mild toast. There is definitely some dark fruit taste in here with fig and prune. Mild bitterness. Nice well rounded mouthfeel.

Sample at GABF 2016. Noted it as 11.0% alcohol. High creamy brown lasting head. Very dark red brown body. Roasted malt straw caramel slightly sour lemon like aroma. Mild and sweet wineous caramel cocoa flavor, little hops bitterness, low carbonation, long finish. Alcohol well hidden.
Poured from 1 pint 9.4 fl oz bottle (February release). Dark brown with tan head. Light caramel malt, very mild chocolate, hint of mild nuts.

Bottle from Albertsons. Seems light on the pour, lots of carbonation, frothy head with sticky lacing. Roast malts on the nose, and then gets deeper in taste. Mefium weight body adds to the experience, it all feels right. Not quite Celebrator, but not too far away either.
On tap. Pours black with brown sticky head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel, toffee, roasted malts, and nut. Taste of same with deep malt bill. Mouthfeel is heavy oily. Drinks like a porter.
Yum, killer beer. Very Malty, smooth lots of toffee, hint of molasses, easy to drink. Love to try again.
Draft sample. The beer is a darker brown with a beige head of foam. The aroma has notes of brown sugar and root beer. The taste is similarly sweet. Bigger body and medium carbonation.
Nice sweet aroma and smokey flavor. Hides alcohol well. Drinkable for an 8% beer.

2009 Vintage finally opened on 2/19/2016, on the week of Double Visions annual release date by Grand Teton. Bottle conditioned, gold-foil labeled 1.0 Liter swing-top bottle. This is the brew chosen to celebrate my 1,000th tasting review on Ratebeer.com. ...and a terrific choice at that! Only wish I had some mates here to share it with. Oh well, all for me will have to work. Notes: mild pop upon opening stirs concern that this might be past its prime. A dimpled mug receives a silky smooth, cola brown pour with nil head. The nose and first taste... a surprise, a success. This is a great Doppelbock! All the aforementioned characteristics are still present seven years on. Bright, strong malty nose of caramel; hay and cereal galore as if there are lambs present; along with some mild spices. Its as if Im tasting this in the middle of a farm. The flavor is very malt-forward as well. Medium sweet and a little bitter roast. Burnt caramel attack that never ends. Full body, thick-sticky texture, mild carbonation and a long mildly roasted finish. Almost a pity I opened this without an audience. Dynamite Dopple!!
Backlog from the Brony Bottle Share at Travlrs. Medium brown with small offwhite head. Malt, coffee, raisins, toffee. Decent.

1" tan head... the head has a definite gold color to it.. the brew is daaark for a dopplebock.. very dark brown but when held to the nearest bulb, it reveals a crystal clear deep ruby color... very pretty..

Nose is thick and very full of heavy malts... not sweet smelling.. just very malty.. sorta a plummy fruitiness... wow.. you dont get this much in doppelbocks (in a good way).. I would expect a long boil or decoction made this one as aromatic as it is.

Flavor is very complex for a doppelbock... a bunch of stuff going on here.. thick maltiness... some slight chocolate... is this what melanoidins taste like???? sorta a pruney frutiness with a bunch of malty sweeness.. but it still seems very drinkable despite the great body and slightly light carbonation.. the only thing that I can complain about is that it may be a tad sticky... but overall, I am damn impressed with this one... very very smooth.. and the complex malt characteristics come in waves as it warms up.. this may be the best example of an American dopplebock that Ive ever had.
Bottle at Brony Tasting, DC. Dark brown, clean clear light roast coffee, chocolate milk. Spicy dark malt. Lots of chocolate. Dark foam. Quite nice.
Bottle at the DC Tasting. Dark brown with off-white head. Aromas of caramel, dark fruit. Tastes of dark fruit, caramel, malt, wheat. Medium-light body with a dry finish.
Very nice stuff. Pours brown with great head and lacing. Lots of coffee and big roast. Quite a decent bitter finish. I really liked this one. Bottle thanks to iphonephan.
From a 75 cl bottle at the Brony bottle share at Travlrs place. Pours a clear cola with an off white head. Aroma of raisins. Flavors of caramel, raisins and nuts. Smooth mouthfeel. Creamy finish.
Pours dark unclear brown . Small white head . Smell is sweet, bit leaves . Taste is bit bitter , chocolaty , caramel , leaves . nice and rather intense .

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2014 i must preface by saying not my choice of styles by any means...bought for Monday new beer tastings at work...poured from bomber 2013 vintage....poured black with a huge creamy long lasting head...nose was a very nice mix of cocoa and berries with malt....mouth was the same with a little anise tossed in....i was way pleased with this one....gonna get another tomorrow....agreeing with slowrunner77 this is more like a stout.

25.4 oz bottle, almost 2 years old. Dark brown with pocked tan foam. Nose is toffee, raisin, cherry, chocolate, tobacco and mild smoke. Creamy medium body with a tang. Taste is caramel, raisin, brown bread and dried apricot with tobacco and smoky notes adding depth and balance. Im surprised this has aged so well.
Nice. Dark pour with minimal head. Aroma is sweet caramel and dark fruit. Taste is sweet version of nose. Like it.

"Not sure what to think of this beer. Suspending expectations, its definitely an enjoyable and decadent beer. If I was really in the mood for a doppelbock, though, this would be a huge miss. Everyones rating is pretty spot on, but for the fact that nobody mentions this is really nothing like any other doppelbock. Pours like a stout, and has very little of the liquid bread aspect the style usually is known for. Lots more choaolte and dark malt. Sweet, almost rum like in its fruitiness, with some yeast and roast coming through as well. So, very nice beer, not a good doppelbock. Reminds me more of a hybrid like Old Viscosity than anything else.
Bottle. Dark brown color, brown head with good retention and solid lacing. Aroma of rich cocoa. Taste is cocoa powder, dried licorice. Nice.

Shared 750 ml. bottle, poured to snifters showing a nearly opaque, darkest brown color, with maybe a little ruby highlighting at the stem, frothy, tan head foam, and spots & strands of lacing. The nose was toasted, nearly roasted notes, with molasses, toffee & caramel, and a hint of salt? Medium+ bodied, carbonation was mild, with the taste showing moderate hop bitterness, modest sweetness, and negligible dark fruit influence. A solid Doppel!

Pours a very dark brown with an everlasting light tan head. Decent aromas of caramel, toffee and toast. Flavors of light peat, caramel, toffee, chocolate and bread. Alcohol shows through just a little. Moderately heavy body. Excellent Doppelbock.

A very nice doppelbock. Pours a beautiful thick black with a tan head. Not much smell, a bit of chocolate. Taste is very smooth and creamy, with a malty start and a bit of hops in the finish. Good stuff. Had on tap at Olde Sonoma Public House.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Purchased in CO and drank in TX. loooooooove this stuff!!!!! Dark pour with red tinge and nice beige head. Great complex aroma of roasted malts slight vanilla dark fruits and some smoke. Taste is similar with some dark fruits caramel and sugars. Absolutely a great beer. Will find more!

Pours a hazy brown with ruby highlights. Has a tan head with decent lacing. Sweet malt aroma with big breadiness and caramel. Hint of oxidation. Sweet malt taste with caramel, brown sugar, a little chocolate and toasted grain. A little oxidation in taste also. Mouthfeel is semi creamy with medium full body and moderate carbonation. Finishes with a bready aftertaste. Would like to try a fresh bottle. Has nice flavors.

Dark brown leather color with some khaki head. Smells of caramel, brown sugar, milk chocolate. Tastes are similar with a small amount roastedness, and some grain and bitter. Almost a lactic taste as well. Possibly some oxidation with this bottle need to try another. Not bad overall but tastes don't mesh well together, but again this could be oxidation related. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at Mikeys Christmas party 
Dark brown with a medium sized tan head and good lacing. Aroma of roasted malts and caramel. Flavors are roasty and chocolate 
Nice

Pours very dark brown, close to black, with a nice tan head. Aroma is rich, with malt and light chocolate notes. Taste is rich and creamy, with complex hoppiness, and caramel, smoked, and licorice notes. A very nice Doppelbock. Thumbs way up.
Reddish brown color, good sized head that lasts. Aroma is bread, caramel, grass, spicy hops, touch of darker fruit. Medium to full body, almost creamy mouthfeel, really nice doppelbock.

750ml bottle. Pours dark brown almost black with a thin tan head. Sweet, caramel, toffee, with a coffee bitterness on the finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A redish brown beer with a creamy, good lacing white head. Aroma is heavy malty and sweet, dark fruits notes. Falvor is sweet and slightly bitter, notes of caramel, alcohol, licorice. Full body and burning alcohol mouthfeel
Pours dark brown with a khaki head. Aroma is caramel, brown sugar, and dark fruit. Flavor is sweet caramel malt, chocolate, smoke, some earthy coffee.

2013 Edition. 750 ml bottle purchased at the brewery. Pours a deep brown with a thin-moderate tan head that lasted through the first two sips and left partial lace. Very pleasant aroma of malt, caramel, mild toast, and a touch of prune. The flavor is similar with malt, caramel, mild toast, prune, and a touch of ash. Mild bitterness at the finish. Nice well rounded mouthfeel.

25.4 ounce bottle. Pours a dark brownish-red with a one inch tan head that lasts. Taste is of roasted malt, caramel, fruit, hops. Similar aroma. Has a nice body with smooth finish. Easy to drink and quite enjoyable.

Opened at an ESBLS but I didnt get to rate it. Sealed and reponed the following night. An almost black pour with just a little red. A beige ring. I smell mostly chocolate but some roasted notes, and some grass in there, too. I taste smoke, coffee, molasses, caramel, along with dark fruit. Ok, some more complex fruit and bready yeast, too. Complex is a good word for this beer. Alcohol is definitely tasted and brings plenty of warming.

Mahogany pour with ruby red highlights and a minimal light brown head that left some lacing. Aroma is caramel, brown sugar, and molasses. Flavor includes cocoa powder, dark fruit, smoke, and roasted malt. Thick, heavy, syrupy mouthfeel which I like for the style.

750 ml. bottle, 25th anniversary edition- Pours very very dark ruby red with a dense creamy tan head that looks like itll stick around. Aroma is very bready, malty, peat moss, mildly smoky. The taste is similar, only smooth and creamy, I dig thie smokiness, very earthy,  leather, chocolate and like the description says, bready, this is a meal in a glass, you could probably live off this stuff. Body is medium and carbonation is medium high. Overall this is great, glad they re-released this, I didnt have a chance to try it the first go around.

Comes out of the tap a luscious dark-chocolate brown with a thick and rather persistent tan head. Rich aroma fills the nose with a strong malt note and caramel, cloves and woody hops in attendance. Scrumptious flavor pleases with a malty core and firm cloves, caramel, earthy and nutty tones - plus an almost bourbon-like alcohol chomp. Syrupy flavor is quite firm and viscous, but fizz leaves a little to be desired. Just be sure that you dont drink this until you get double vision - and if you do, PLEASE call a cab.
On tap. Dark red to brown with a tan top. Malty nose. Taste is chocolate and nuts .

Pours dark with creamy head. Not much aroma. Mod to full body with nice chocolate finish

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Reddish brown, almost black in color... Aroma of chocolate, caramel malts... Rich flavor of caramel, toffee, chocolates, notes of dates and licorice... Sweet nutty finish.. Solid

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a nice dark hue. Served in a pint glass with pretty decent lacing. Tastes of a strong coffee essence especially at the end. Smooth caramel finish almost reminiscent of a stout. Exceeded expectations.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2014 Aroma is super earthy. Hint of syrupy molasses. Bitter.... 
Appearance is OK. Limited head retention. Otherwise its very dark brown.
Taste is overly earthy. Malty sweet molasses taste. Finish is dull. I mean.... its OK but not great.
Palate is OK. The sweetness battles with the bitterness rather than a compliment.

This beer is really lacking in balance. This really drink like a beer cocktail between a light ale and a big dark stout and it just isnt working. Not bad but not great.

Update: my first official collaring 

Aroma from three to five. Lighter aroma. Metallic. Nothing special
Taste is a little chocolate but huge early hop note. Stays a 6. 
Yeah.... Upped the aroma a bit but overall really no change. Sucks that it was a not so good one to begin with.

~Bready chocolatey aroma with slight smokiness and spicy hops 
 ~Pours a dark brown color with ruby tints. Lasting creamy off white head 
~ Bready milk chocolate flavor some woody and smokey notes with spicy hops 
 ~Medium full bodied with medium co2 creamy chocolatey feel. Malty chocolate finish. 
 ~Excellent brew. Could drink quite a bit of this on a cool evening. Chocolate notes are great.

750 ml. bottle. Pours a thick, well retained, light beige head, with some lacing, over a clear, dark brown (SRM 30) body.....nose is cocoa, chocolate, light plum.....taste is sweet chocolate, cocoa, toffee/caramel, light raisin, hints of plum, finishing sweet.....mouth feel thick, chewy, alcohol hidden, carbonation adds creamy texture. This falls well within the style. It lacks some of the rich fruit aromas and flavors of the best and the cocoa chocolate roasted malts dominate a bit too much. It even edges towards being an Imperial Brown, but many of the flavors are like a Cadbury caramel Easter Egg.  BJCP 8/3/14/4/7
Not o fan of doppelbocks but this is the best iv had.  Very roasty.  Almost like a porter.  Crisp finish.

Pours a deep brown with a medium tan head.  The aroma is rather complex.  I find caramel, raisin, chocolate, apple, coffee, and roasted malts.  There is a lot going on here.  The taste leans more to the malty side of things, while still retaining some fruity elements.  Up front I get caramel, coffee, and licorice.  This continues with these elements into raisin and chocolate.  It has some tartness in here, and is a little bit bitter.  The aftertaste is coffee and chocolate and is pretty strong.  Full bodied with a more thick texture.  Although this isnt my favorite style, I must say that this is a very well made and complicated beer.  Its good, and Im sure that others will enjoy this more than I did.  I just feel that there is a bit to much going on here for me to really appreciate what its offering.

A finger of tan head on a dark brown body. Looks great.
The aroma is wonderful: burnt and roasted malt and caramel.
The taste is dark and complex. Burnt wood and mild lemon bitterness rounded out by caramel sweetness. 
The texture is smooth, just short of creamy with moderate carbonation.
A excellent drink.
Tap at 8th street grill.  Pours reddish brown, malty and hoppy at the end

An excellent drink. Pours black with brown head and very nice lacing. Aromas are sweet raisins and candy....lots of malty goodness too. I love the warm boozy flavours, sweet dried fruit in there too. A great winter sipper.

Holy smokes, what a brew. Pours deep dark brown to black, with hues of ruby black where the light gets through. Subtle alcohol and carbonation, aroma is ripe with plum, stone fruit, biscuits, and creme brulee. Pours with a generous tan head that slowly disappears.

Tasting notes of coffee, roasted barley, yeast, earthy. Delicious and damn near perfect!

Pours almost coffee black with a tan head that stays. Aromas of light chocolate malts and some caramel but a bit faint. Flavor is mainly a big malt punch with some slight coffee bitterness but is still rather drinkable and the alcohol is almost non-existent.  In the realm of dopplebocks, this one might be one of the best Ive had.
pours black with a tight tanned head. Nose of coffee. Aroma of dark malts, coffee. Medium bitterness, medium bodied. Enjoyed it.

This good looking deep black colored beer has a yeasty banana bread aroma. It has a smoky bitter chocolate flavor. A good sipping beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap. Reddish brown pour with a small spotty head. Very malty - caramel and bread. Some hop kick on the taste. Solid!

Pours a clear, deep brown with a small beige head. Aroma is smokey with malt and coffee. Flavor is malty with caramel and nutty notes and also a very smokey quality with some coffee and sugars. Medium body with medium carbonation and some sweet alcohol noticeable on the finish. Very flavorful.
Drank this on tap at happy gnome with the owners son. Pretty cool experience. Nice color. Good lacing. Chocolate bread nose. Dark fruit namely raisin. Really nice beer

Appearance:  Pours dark brown with a decent cap of tight nit tan head.

Aroma:  Coffee like roast, grain, cereal and dark chocolate.



Taste:  Dark roast, minerals, a touch of wood/smoke, dark chocolate, pumpernickel. Beneath all the savory, smoke and bitter chocolate is a little bit of sweetness.

Mouthfeel:  Full bodied, easy going carbonation.

Overall:  While not much like some of the German Doppelbocks Ive tried, this was big, bold, flavorful and most importantly, enjoyable.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2013 Update: latest batch in 2013 is even a bit darker, showing notes of chocolate, caramel, and even a bit of roast. Nearly approaching a Baltic porter. #sample

12oz bottle, courtesy of Grand Teton. Thanks! Pours a deep, reddish-caramel color; fine-bubbled medium tan head with modest lacing. Nicely handled nose: caramel, dried dark fruits (dates, raisins), and toasty brown sugar throughout; a beautifully bready, caramel-driven aroma that keeps from cloying. Medium-full body; medium to medium-high carbonation (a touch high, and if anything the most obvious element pointing to American origins... besides the hop bill); certainly a mouthful, with a pleasant, lifting acidity. Theres definitely plenty of malt depth here - caramel, brown sugar, toffee... - along with an atypically assertive hop presence, hinting at citrus and floral depth, with a firm bitterness in any event; clean yeast character, and a flawless presentation overall: steely minerals, solid citrus bitterness, layered caramel and restrained maltiness; the hops and the carbonation give it away. Lasting finish of brown sugar and light cereal-grain toastiness; the slightest sweetness.
3rd October 2009Bottle from a Las Vegas liquor store. Dark brown beer. Softish semi dry palate. Silky rich malt with marmite. A little malt cream. Pinch of spice. Drinkable.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2013 This is what i want in a lager. . Pours a very dark garnet red with some tan lingering fizz. The aroma is sweet malty and rich with a little smoke. The taste is AMAZING, some dark raisin, toasted caramel, hefty malt with a light smoke and creamy nuttiness, a little bitter chocolate, some subtle German hops to give it some balance.  They did it to highlight their brewing water and this thing goes down too easy and lingers for a while. I love German style beers and this has got to be the best American doppelbock i have ever had. Grab this if you see it, seriously.

Thanks to Alex for this liter pour... dark brown with a light tan head, gone quickly... the aroma is awesome, great malty base that really reminds me of a Kuhnhenn beer, accented by some bread and  molasses, smalls awesome!... the taste is restrained, but really nice, bread molasses... possibly the best dopplebock Ive had
Tap. NITRO. Smooth and creamy, like drinking melted chocolate. This beer has aroma and flavor of smoky sweet caramel and bready malts and chocolate. Wonderful beer.

As Doppels go, this kicks ass.  Really quite the best of the style up there with Celebrator and Asam-Bock.  Thick, rich, malty, chewy, like liquid brown sugar, the sweet parts of banana bread extracted into drinkable format.  Bottle has "2009" label; Im surprised that it is good after that long a time . . . ?

Goes well with: Kayo Dot, "___On Limpid Form"

Aged 1 year. Pours deep mahogany into a Stem glass. Mocha head with medium retention recedes to pancake surface leaving spot lacing. Smoked sweet caramel aromas. Creamy with upfront anise, dark caramel and resin turning slightly smoky in the lasting pleasantly hopped black pepper finish.

1L bottle, dated 2/10/2009.  Poured a lovely shade of deep brown with a luscious beige head.. looked great!  The aroma picked up deep molasses, drawn caramel, and tarry malts accented by smoke and faint elderberries.. warmer on the back of the nose, indicating some warmth.. most excellent.  The flavor found a tasty blend of malts, with black roasted, lightly-smoked black patent and chocolate notes over a bed of bready malt and caramel.. not much bitterness or overt alcohol to note.. finished semi-sweet and malty.  Medium-bodied with low-moderate carbonation on the palate.. this flowed well and was enjoyable the whole way through.

Bottle ...Deep amber pour , thin beige head , sparse lacing .  Sweet Munich malt aroma with a touch of smokiness .  Sweet , sticky caramel flavor , some breadiness and nuttiness . Full bodied , thick and chewy . Warming alcohol in the finish , sweet for a style known for sweetness .

Well let at my username. Great example of the style. Deep cloudy brown color with thick tan head. Aroma of biscuits and malts smacks you in the face. Molasses, raisins, coffee, some licorice and well subtle hopiness to even out the alcohol content.

1L bottle from BevMo - 

Aroma - the aroma on this one is almost worth the price of admission, and the price on this 1L bottle is kinda hefty.  Huge blast of toasted raisin bread, hefty caramel notes, chocolate cake batter, brown sugar,  molasses...just insane.  

Appearance - dark chocolate brown body, nearly black with a medium thick creamy tan head.  

Taste - the flavor on this beer matches nearly in perfect step with the wonderful aroma.  Heapings of brown sugar, vanilla, raisins, caramel...its definitely a malt monster and its fantastic.

Palate - thick, rather heavy-handed on the palate, viscuous and coating

Overall - one of the best beers Ive had in recent memory and while skeptical of the price on this huge bomber, the contents inside are well, well worth it.  Very suprising.

2009 1L swing top bottle.  Pours murky brown with a quickly dissipating tan head into a stem glass; fades to foamy lacing.  Oh yeah, this is a doppelbock.  More cocoa than Ive ever seen in this style on the nose, raisin, vanilla, quite malty with an earthy/woodsy character as well, toasted bread.  Again, the cocoa comes out significantly in the flavor.  Its robust with a roasty, almost smoky quality.  Toasty malt carries throughout.  Wow this is good, hard to put it down to take notes.  Molasses and black licorice creep in.  The finish has more rich cocoa, vanilla, caramel, woodsy.  A splash of booze is noticeable as well with a rich tobacco aftertaste.  Medium to full bodied with a velvety, chewy mouthfeel and a low level of carbonation.  Despite the abv, this is highly drinkable.  Smooth, rich, enormously complex, phenomenal.  By far the best doppelbock Ive ever had.  Well done Grand Teton.

Pours deep brown with off white head, aroma is smoke, molasses, bread, and some other dark malt.  Taste is sweet with molasses, caramel, some toffee and bread with a smoky and vanilla undertone.  Good brew.

Bottle. Average beige creamy head that mostly diminished. Fair display of lacework. Mahogany color. Aroma of dried fruit, vanilla, rye bread, caramel, molasses, hint of grain and mild toasted malt. Medium to full bodied with a soft carbonation and light alcoholic texture. Heavy sweet flavor. Lingering dried fruity finish. 
8 / 3 / 8 / 4 / 17 = 4.0

Bottle at the Rosso release at Captain Lawrence.  Pours brown with a thin beige head.  Big oxidized caramel.  Plums, more oxidization and ruddy caramel.  Long sweet tannic finish with yet more caramel.  Rather tasty.

Bottle 100cl. @ Papsoes blindtasting. [ Bottle #25. ]Clear dark red brown color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is light heavy malty, roasted, caramel, pumpernickel, light chocolate. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, dark berry. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100327]

Sampled from the bottle at the 2010 March Metro Detroit tasting. Poured a dark hazy brown with a brown head. Aroma had notes of smoke, dark malts and a hint of vanilla. Flavor had notes of vanilla and caramel with an undertone of roasted malts.

Tasting at Papsø, 2009 Cellar ReserveThe color is almost black, there is only little carbonation left. The caramel - chocolatey aroma is a bit phenolic. Sweetish caramel and chocolate flavor, with little wood character, a bit oxidised. Correct bitterness. Its not enough to have the name to be a Doppelbock; its more of a sweet Imperial Porter.
Bottled. A dark red beer with a thin head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of caramel, alcohol, malt, and fruit, leading to a dry finish. Quite  nice.
Clear deep red/brown - white head. Chocolate, cocoa, vineous, vanilla, cheep chocolate, light carbonated, light spicy, light herbal, fruity, dark bread.

Bottle. Very dark reddish brown with a dense tan head. The aroma is chocolate, roast, vinous and burned caramel. The flavour is chocolate, ripe fruit, some roast, oak, vanilla nd light alcohol. Nice creamy texture.

papsoe blind tasting beer#25:
very dark, dark amber, small light brown head. 
aroma is licorice, dark caramelly, sweet malty, faint roasted grains, faint 
spicy. 
flavor is roasted grains, toffee, caramel, rye.

Bottle #25 at Papsøs blindtasting.
Clear red brown coloured with a medium sized beige head.
Sweet aroma of caramel with notes of dried fruits and hops.
Sweet flavour of caramel, dried fruits, hops and alcohol.
Sweet and warming alcoholic finish.
Bottle @ Papsø. Tasted blind. Pours dark brown - nearly black with a small off white head. Nose & taste is sweet caramel, toffee and fruit. Very vinous and smooth. Tasty

1 L bottle, courtesy of Papsoe. Pours dark brown to black with a small tan head. Aroma is subdued fruity to the dark malt flavours. Sweet caramelish flavoured, slight sticky texture. Dark malty. Sweet and caramelish into a nice lingering malty finish.

Bottle 100 cl. Courtesy of byaeger. Pours a dark reddish brown with an off-white head. Sweet overripe dark fruit in the nose with some overripe fruit. Solid body with a massive base of nuts, roasted malt and pumpernickel. Sweet burned caramel. Warming alcohol finish with hardly any bitterness. 270310
Draught at Sycamore. Chocolate and malty pour with some bourbon flavor.  Dark with nice carbonation. Some desert like sweetness. Very well done and hides its lager status easily.

freebie. consumed 10/23/2009.

dark burgundy/garnet brown with an orange tinted khaki colored head. 

the aroma is intensely nutty... followed by chocolate, brown sugar, minerality similar to co2, rootbeer and a light sourness from fruity notes of prunes and dried things. it smells a lot like two turtle doves???.

the flavor is full of chocolate, malt and brown sugar with lesser notes of cola, birch, roasted nuts, molasses, raisins and a slight ashiness. there is a mild sourness/tartness on the finish which helps clean it up. it is a bit on the sweeter side of what i prefer but that certainly does not slow me down this time. 

the full body is very rich while the mouth feel is slick from the low carbonation. 8/4/8/4/15/3.9
( 1L bottle 2009 vintage thanks to bu11zeye) Pours clear brown red with oily bubbles. Nose of rum raisins, milk chocolate. Taste of brown sugar, caramel with nice body and a sweet finish.

Dark brown, thin beige head head. Aroma- candy, sweet malt. Taste- not as sweet as it smells. Rich roasted barley with a slightly burnt caramel undertone. Dense, chewy and slightly hoppy finish. Very nice.

Bottle provided by bu11zeye and tasted at thirdeye11s birthday tasting.

Pours brown with a light brown head. Aroma is sweet toffee with some chocolate and roasted nuts. The flavor is more of the same with sweet caramel, toffee and some alcohol. A very flavorful and drinkable doppelbock. Medium mouthfeel.

bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  poured dark murky brown with an off white head.  aroma of caramel, dark fruit, spice, grain, and raisin.  flavor was much the same with the addition of chocolate and alcohol.  light slick body with low carbonation.

( 1L swing-top bottle )  Pours a mahogany body with a small cream head.  Aroma of caramel, fudge, raisins, molasses, and dates.  Flavor of raisins, brown sugar, chocolate, roasted malt, caramel, and vinous.  Tasty.
bottle, thanks to bu11zeye, dark brown with excellent chocolatey , malty and roast nut aroma, flavors of cocoa, malt, leather, roast nuts, with a great rolling finsh
UPDATED: DEC 24, 2009 bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  deep chocolate, cream head.  roasted malts and caramel nose.  smooth palate, roasted malt flavor, followed by caramel and more roastiness.
Bottle courtesy of bu11zeye. Clear rouge color. Nice chocolate smell with roasted notes on the nose. Taste has smooth flavor and nice roasted elements. Its very well done.

1L swingtop at Rhinos on Thanksgiving with Dom. Besides the expensive packaging, this was a nice doppelbock. Real fresh, clean aroma and flavour that was not heavy on the molassas notes that sometimes dominate this style. Rather pleasant and went great with turkey!

1L Swingtop: Pours a dark chewy raisin color with a nice fluffy brown head and tons of lacing. The nose is fresh and fruity with lots of cherry, dark chocolate, raisin, oak and smoky rye. The flavor is nice and chewy; more dark dried fruits and rich caramel malts. Nice carob note in the tail with a very balanced body and creamy mouthfeel. A tiny bit vegetal but its offset by the bright acidity from the heavier roasted malts and clean fresh hops. Probably my favorite of the Cellar Reserve series.

Sampled at Great Tucson Beer Festival.  Mahogany pour with ruby red highlights and a minimal light brown head that left some lacing.  Aroma is caramel, brown sugar, and molasses.  Flavor includes cocoa powder, dark fruit, smoke, and roasted malt.  Thick, heavy, syrupy mouthfeel which I like for the style.  Not a bad brew but wouldnt get the monster bottle.

Bottle pours brown in color with a minimal khaki colored head.  Aroma is heavy in chocolate, brown sugar, and prune with a tiny hint of smoke. On first sip, the only thing I can think is that Im glad Im not trying to drink this beast alone. Flavor carries over the above with additional notes of molasses, black currant, and heavy roasted malt with a touch of alcohol.  The mouthfeel is thick and oily, just how I like it, yet somehow Im just not impressed. Probably the prune. Maybe I would have liked it better with some food, just lacks the integration.

At The Rose and Crown in Palo Alto. They ran out of IPA on tap, so they tree this one in with a big $3 sign on it. The bartender said this would appeal to fans of Pliny the Elder. I didnt quite follow his logic, but for 3 bucks, I decided to give it a shot. Its got a burnt, chocolate sort of taste. Its just not my style. Dark, cola brown. Might be a good one for people who like the style, but I may struggle to finish his one.

Giant swing-top bottle at Beer in the Park.   Id seen this beer around earlier in the year, but the high price and large bottle in a hit-or-miss style for me kept it out of my hands.   A five ounce pour was just perfect, actually, and I cant imagine drinking an entire bottle of this.   The aroma is a nice blend of cherry and chocolate.   The flavor is big malts that are just very typical of the style, with a burnt toast and over-ripe fruit, balanced by a medium bitterness.  Thick in the mouth.   Nice aromatics and a decent flavor balance, but this is just to hard to drink for me to ever buy.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown with an average, rocky light brown head, somewhat lasting with fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, caramel, toffee), light hop (herbs), average yeast (dough, broth) with notes of alcohol, oak, brown sugar, and plum.  Full bodied, creamy texture, lively carbonation, and an astringent finish.  Long duration, heavy sweetness, light acidity and bitterness.

Draught @ TFD - Pours dk brown with a small beige head...aroma is cocoa, roasted malt and spice...flavour is sweet without being cloying, bitter chocolate, molassas, toast...nice dark fruit on the finish...tasty...

1 liter swing top bottle from Bevmo. Pours an opaque dark brown color with a medium khaki head that has good retention and some lacing. The aroma is sweet with roasted malts and molasses. The flavor is similar to the aroma, plenty of molasses, brown sugar, licorice, dark roasted malts and perhaps some charcoal. The mouthfeel is full and creamy smooth. The finish is long with lingering molasses. This is one fine dopplebock, one of the best of its style.
A sweet malty caramel, light smoke aroma. The flavor on this interesting, definitely has some upfront heft to it, as well as sweetness and smoke. Pretty nice, if a tad sweet at first. Quite pricey.
1L swing top.  Pours deep brown with a ruby hue, head was thick and beige in color.  Lots of thick chocolate malts and candied dark fruits.  Brew was very thick and rich, a great Doppelbock.

This dark brown ale poured with a decent tan head and a toffee aroma. Its a little sweet, even for a doppelbock, but its chewy and tasty. Lots of chocolate, fruit and caramel malt, and lots of flavor.

Now were getting somewhere. This is the year of the Dopplebock. Everyone has one out but this one really shines on the extremity of it all. Very dark brownish amber in color with excellent aromamanship. Thick and latherous. Chewy and creamy. A rather large malt backbone protrudes and claims the very essence of this beer. Chunky chocolate malted milk balls are very enjoyable in liquid form. The finish lasts with lingering bitter cocoa. I mammoth of a beer.

Cellar Reserve 2009 (bottled 2/1/2009) 1L bottle (I think it is 1L). Pours with a large, fluffy, tan head over a huge near black body. Aroma of dark fruits, spice, chocolate, cherry, alcohol and plum. Taste is dark fruits, chocolate, cherry, earth, caramel, smoke and light rotten fruits. Great paring for the BBQ pork chop I had with it. Velvety mouthfeel with light carbonation.

Bottle shared by DYCSoccer17. Dark garnet with frothy tan head. Earthy, basement tones; mushroomy. Light coffee roast, acidic. Sweetish, flat coffee flavor, more earthy/mushroom notes. Sweet, dark chocolate finish, moderate bitterness.

1 Liter bottle purchased at BevMo in Vacaville, CA.  Bottle 02/10/2009.  Musty anise aroma with some choco notes.  This kinda smells like burning tires.  Lacks the sweetness that I would like.  Mostly hazy mahogany body with a yellow-tan head and nice lacing.  Kind of chalky start before this becomes sweet and then a little bitter with chocolate.  Lightly metallic and quite a bit of coffee-like roastiness.  Pretty different, but tasty enough.  Has some lingering mustiness, though.
Very rich malt with molasses and a little chocolate. Full bodied and surprisingly sticky. Tasty.

Pours a rich dark ruby to black color with tan head that rises quite well and dissipates to a thin rim lace.  Nose is very traditional for the style with plenty of "goats breath" dark bread breadyness, perhaps a suggestion towards a dessert cake (Black Forest Chocolate?), and a slight fruityness in the mix - maybe a jammy fig or dark cherry.  Palate is a whopper with roasty malt, caramel, and just enough hop bitterness to keep it from being too sweet.  Finish is long, malty, and rich.  Excellent example of a doppelbock.

Bottle shared at a BeerAdvocate gathering.  Pours nearly black in color with a tan head.  Smoky aroma with chocolate and roast.  Flavor is smoke, chocolate, roast, molasses, dark fruit, and mixed nuts.  Creamy, medium-full palate.  Great stuff.

Bottle This beer rocks! Pours nearly black with a mid-sized, creamy, lightly tanned head. Fantastic retention. The aroma is very nice. Rich mocha nose with a touch of ethanol. Full-bodied and silky with gentle carbonation. This has the aroma, the mouthfeel and all the flavor of an imperial porter  big, malty, mocha sweetness. A semblance of balance is provided by modest, minerally bitterness. Chocolaty, well-roasted, mildly bitter finish. Not really what I was expecting from a doppelbock, but this is a best-of-show site, so I either like the beer or I dont. I love it!

Aroma was German dark bready malts with slight hints of chocolate brownie mix, not overwhelming,flavor however was was a huge surprise,Lucious huge melatoidin malting ,rich chocolate and molassas saturated cake,a little bit of roastedness also, pretty much breaking all the rules of a dopple,but this is one of the best dopples I have ever tasted,the only better might have been a fresh glass of Andesch in Munich. The flavor keep its rich body right to the end. A little bitter in the finish,again unusal for a dopple, but a real treat,a little pricey ,but this one is worth at least one try

Big 1 liter swing top bottle that thankfully is not covered with that annoying wax. It  poured a rich looking clear dark red that looked brown in the glass with a fat tan head and very sticky lacing rings. Nose of ripe fruit and a peppery spicy aroma.  Medium body but a very smooth mouthfeel. Flavor of both ripe fruit and chocolate.   Malty finish. A very well crafted and highly drinkable Doppelbock and another winner in the Cellar Reserve series.

1 litre swing top bottle poured a clear dark brown with garnet highlights and a small lingering amber head. Aromas of dark fruit, pepper, molasses, bitter chocolate, dark bread and a hint of smoke. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of dark bread, molasses, dark fruit, dark chocolate and light smoke with a smooth lingering malty finish.
Bottle shared by Hophead22.. Dark brown with beige head.. Smelt like peppered tomatoes..Kinda has that pepper spicyness and molasses sweetness... Kinda tastyness

Bottle. Dark brown beer with a light brown head. Chocolate malt and light roast aroma. Sweet malt with toffee and chocolate and light roast flavor. Medium bodied. Toffee lingers with some sweet malt, caramel, and light roast. Nice.

Thanks for sharing this bottle Stephen (Darkelf).  Pours with a cloudy, brown body topped by a thin to medium thick head with some lacing left on the glass.  Its sweet and malty with a note of roast and molasses.  Full bodied and smooth yet warming.

Bottle shared by Hophead22.  Pours an almost black brown with a light brown head.  Aroma is very peppery and herbal with some under ripe fruits, vegetables, and bread.  Flavor is again spicy, some chocolate and molasses.  Palate is creamy and full bodied and it finishes a bit sticky.

1ltr bottle shared with DuffManSW and mspindler.. Very dark brown pour with a tan head. Spicy, pepper was mentioned, which fits quite well. Chocolate flavor, some spiciness too, dark fruits. Pretty good.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Bottle:  First off, THANK YOU Grand Teton for not dipping another swingtop in wax!  Ive damn near severed my finger and sipped bits of wax too many times.  That being said, this pours an intoxicating auburn color with a large, creamy nutmeg colored head.  Nose is sweet, malty, fruity, and a little toffee.  Tastes sweet with malts and darker fruitiness, some toffee, and caramel.  A little floral tingle in the finish, along with a sense of the abv.  This was shockingly good.  About time GT!
Poured dark brown, smooth, sweet,  roasted malts, chocolate, little licorice little coffee, little vanilla, litttle dark fruits.
Bottle from Bevmo.  Dark brown with a fizzy of white head.  Nice toasty caramel, buttery, and toffee taste.  Quite good.

Dark brown color with a hint of umber when held to the light. A diminished head of small, light tan bubbles form a thin lid. Heavy caramel, toasted malt, leather, light spice and some DMS (mostly creamed corn) in the nose. Not the clean malty aroma I need from my doppels. Smooth and lightly oily in feel. A decent feel for an ESB or Barleywine, but a little too sappy and no real zip for a lager. Toasted malt and caramel in the flavors. Too much licorice and wood for my liking in the middle. Finish has a bit of husky grain and finish is light with some fruit sweetness. Im not sure about this one. Its not a bad brew, but it is no doppelbock - at least in my book. A strong American brew, that sounds nice.

Sampled on 3/25/2009. This dopplebock pours a eclipse black color form a 1 litter swing-top bottle. Medium to small sized beige foamy head with nice retention and good lacing. The aroma is chocolate, coffee, some vanilla, and dark fruits. A medium bodied dopplebock. The malts are chocolate, coffee, roasty malts, touch of toffee and vanilla. The hops are earthy and floral. Nice balance. Very smooth taste, nearly creamy. Very nice soft carbonation. Great sipping beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

One liter BC swingtop bottle from BevMo. 2009! Dark reddish color with a huge, frothy dark beige head. Rich roasted malt aroma. Full bodied with creamy carbonation. Flavor is strongly roasted caramel with some smokey notes. Some light hop, but the finish is less than dry and not too bitter. Such bitter as there is seems to come from the roasted malt. Very smooth and silky. Keep thinking theres bits of chocolate and coffee. Probably not. Excellent beer.
